Award.AwardTitle: Household Financial Vulnerability and Immigrant Assimilation in the United States

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Directorate of Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences offers postdoctoral research fellowships to provide opportunities for recent doctoral graduates to obtain additional training, to gain research experience under the sponsorship of established scientists, and to broaden their scientific horizons beyond their undergraduate and graduate training. Postdoctoral fellowships are further designed to assist new scientists to direct their research efforts across traditional disciplinary lines and to avail themselves of unique research resources, sites, and facilities, including at foreign locations. This postdoctoral fellowship award supports a rising social science scholar studying the costs and consequences borne by U.S. households as an outcome of local, state and federal immigration enforcement activity; and to examine the impacts of these financial burdens on everyday household decision-making, socio-economic vulnerability and long-term assimilation. he research has significant implications for U.S. immigration and boundary enforcement policy. For example, research already conducted in immigrant-sending communities shows how enforcement activity produces significant financial hardships that have counter-intuitive outcomes, driving patterns of unlawful migration as households and extended family networks seek to spread and mitigate risk. In cities like Tucson and Detroit, immigrant households concentrate disproportionately in low-income enclaves where residents deal with the burdens of under- or marginal employment; under-performing schools; high rates of crime; unstable housing conditions; and exclusion from mainstream financial institutions. This research examines the strategies used by such households to meet the acute financial burdens associated with a household member's exposure to immigration detention and removal, and how these strategies affect household members' short- and long-term socio-economic opportunities, vulnerabilities, and assimilation into the fabric of U.S. life. A key feature of the research involves the recruitment, training, coaching and supervision of bilingual first-generation undergraduate students, who will assist in the collection and analysis of data and dissemination of research results. The involvement of these students is intended to encourage their completion of a four-year degree and to increase their familiarity with and excitement about SBE-related fields. At the conclusion of research activities, the PI and sponsoring scientist will conduct a program evaluation with participating undergraduate student researchers. This will allow for assessment of research, training and mentorship activities, and will inform the dissemination of the research and training model for broader application and use by peer scholars and educators.

Research data are collected using a 72-item, in-person detailed questionnaire, with questions related to household finances, assets, immigration history, and social networks of instrumental support used to mitigate risks (e.g., extended family who provide loans or childcare services in an emergency). Responses are entered into a central database and analyzed for bivariate and multivariate associations and compared to national and local estimates of wealth and debt obtained by the U.S. Census Bureau. For purposes of comparison, data will be collected in two research sites: Tucson, Arizona and Detroit, Michigan. The target sample size is 100 interviews in each site. Respondents are identified using canvassing and snowball sampling at sites where immigrant families receive services such as churches, clinics and other non-profit organizations. Bilingual undergraduate students are recruited in Tucson and Detroit to assist with data collection and data entry. Student researchers are recruited through the University of Arizona (UA)'s ASEMS program, which provides coaching and support to undergraduate students pursuing a degree in a STEM field; the UA's Department of Mexican-American Studies, which promotes the research opportunities described above to students enrolled in its classes; and Pima Community College's "Upward Bound" program, a U.S. Department of Education-funded initiative that provides first-generation, low-income students with coaching and support to accomplish a four-year college degree. All undergraduate research assistants recruited and involved in research activities are trained in mixed-method data collection and human subjects protocols. Research assistants receive ongoing coaching, supervision and hands-on experience as they contribute to research outcomes. To disseminate these outcomes a "white paper" highlighting key findings will be produced and made available to local, state and national elected leaders and to not-for-profit advocacy organizations. Presentations of key findings, in English and Spanish, will be offered to all participants via recruitment sites, as well as to advocacy networks and policy-makers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past fifteen years immigration detention and removal in the United States has expanded dramatically.  For example, between fiscal years 2002 and 2013 formal removals from the United States jumped roughly 260%, from 165,168 to 438,421.  There are three primary drivers of this expansion of immigration policing:

  1. The convergence of immigration and criminal law, such that expanding categories of non-citizens in the United States have been rendered deportable
  2. The redirection of considerable federal resources toward the task of identifying, detaining and removing deportable individuals, and;
  3. The proliferation of non-federal police jurisdictions involved in immigration policing, through active or passive cooperation with federal authorities.

These three conditions combine to focus intense policing experienced disproportionately by one subsection of the U.S. population: non-citizens and the family members of non-citizens who are affected by the threat of detention or removal of their loved ones.  The vulnerabilities produced by these patterns of policing are considerable, constraining individual opportunities and household conditions of social reproduction (i.e., the everyday activities and infrastructures required to sustain life and prepare individuals for formal, waged work).  Sociologists, anthropologists and geographers have studied many of these vulnerabilities, including those associated with the workplace, education, health outcomes and family life.  Less understood have been the financial costs that accumulate directly from personal and household exposure to immigration enforcement, and how these costs aggregate and reverberate through social and community networks. 

This research sought to undertake a preliminary investigation of the financial impacts of household exposure to immigration policing in the United States. 

Research subjects were asked to complete a 110-item questionnaire that includes questions about household composition, finances, immigration history, and short and long-term plans related to education, residence and livelihood.  In total the research team completed 149 household questionnaires. The research population was restricted to residents of a household in Pima County, AZ that has experienced an immigration arrest since 1994 - regardless of the final outcome of any individual immigration case.

The research findings reveal significant financial strains accumulating to households as a result of an immigration arrest. 96.8% of households report at least one United States Citizen or Lawful Permanent Resident. The average total direct costs to each household stemming from an immigration arrest is $10,737.21; while when indirect costs (lost economic opportunity) are added this cost increases to $22,853.51. In addition to direct and indirect financial costs, respondents reported on long-term impacts of exposure to immigration policing on household members including loss of financial assets, loss of financial stability, loss of residential stability, loss of employment and prolonged unemployment, debt, suicide, divorce, deteriorating mental and physical health, declining school attendance and performance, loss of a primary care giver, and elevated levels of anxiety and fear when performing routine tasks.

Intellectual Merit

Data on the financial costs associated with immigration policing advances the field of financial geography into a substantively new area of inquiry, and fills a broad gap in the scholarly literature related to this under-studied dimension of socio-economic vulnerability in the United States. Research results are currently being incorporated into at least three single and co-authored manuscripts that will be submitted for peer-review in leading academic journals associated with the disciplines of geography and criminology. A white-paper report intended for public dissemination among local, state and national policymakers; non-profit advocacy organizations; and research populations is presently being prepared for release in February 2019.

Broader Impacts

Methodologically, the research was structured around the recruitment of 13 bilingual first-generation undergraduate students, who participated as paid research assistants. All undergraduate research assistants received a 40-hour research training in mixed-methods and human subjects research. These research assistants contributed to data collection and data entry, and received regular mentorship, oversight and feedback from the PIs. The involvement of these 13 undergraduate research assistants was expressly intended to encourage the academic success of students from populations under-represented in higher education; to support their completion of a four-year degree; and to increase the visibility of the University of Arizona and Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences-related research activities in under-served communities. At the conclusion of research activities, all research assistants were invited to complete a program evaluation to help assess research activities and improve teaching and training activities in future research efforts, as well as the sharing of the research model for future application.  Finally, the research and mentorship opportunities afforded through this fellowship supported the career advancement of the research fellow, who was able to develop experience mentoring and overseeing undergraduate students in the conduct of research; undertake additional professional training in quantitative data analysis and mixed-methods research; develop a model for incorporating research activities into undergraduate curricula; expand research and publication areas into new areas of inquiry; and develop a new pool of data from which to expand on previous research publications.
